Stings

Table of contents

  • 1. 3. Stings

1. 3. Stings

October 6 1962 1

Bare-handed, I hand the combs.
The man in white smiles, bare-handed._
our cheesecloth gauntlets [...] neat a sweet,
The throath of our wrists [...]brave lilies.
The [...] combs are a [...] mahogan
He & I, he and I
Have a thousand clean cells between us,
⟨Eight ⟩comb after combs of yellow cups,
⟨and ⟩The hive itself [...] a teacup,
White [...] with pink flowers on it [...].
With excessive love I enamelled it
Thinking [...] "Sweetness, Sweetness",
[...]
The Brood cells [...] grey as the fossils of shells
terrifyied me, they seem [...] so old.
What was am I buying, [...] warmy mahogany?
⟨Is⟩ Was there any queen at all in it?
If there is, [...]she [...]is old, [...]
Her wings torn shawls, her long body
Rubbed of its plush—
Poor and bare, poor and bare & unqueenly & even shameful.
I think I am being [...]
I stand in a column
Of winged, unmiraculous women,
Honey-drudgers. I am no drudge
I am no drudge
Though for sevensix years I have eaten dust
And dried plates with my dense [...] [...] hair.
And seen my strangeness evaporate,
Blue dew from dangerous skin.
Will they hate me,
these women who only scurry,
Whose [...] news is the open cherry, is the [...] open clover?
Home 
Sylvia Plath. Date: 2023-03-31
